docs.text: Getting Started This guide explains how to get YourGameLib, create a user project and run it. TL;DR If you are in a hurry, grab the pre-initialized template YourGameProject.zip and jump to Build the project . You need Git , CMake and a C/C++ compiler , as mentioned below. Pro: Fast, easy, Python not required Con: Manually rename "YourGameProject" across multiple files The recommended way for initializing a new project is following this guide, though. Requirements The list of requirements for getting started: Git 1.7.0+ Python 3.5+ with Jinja2 gitpython CMake 3.6+ A common C/C++ compiler capable of C++11 Installation With YourGameLib, user projects get access to the YourGame API and a selected number of third-party libraries, to work with directly. YourGameLib is always built from source in user project context. Let's get the code by cloning the repository: git clone --depth 1 https://github.com/duddel/yourgamelib.git Installation done. Initialize a User Project Initialize a new user project by running the init.py script from the just cloned yourgamelib directory. This creates the directory ./MyGame/ next to ./yourgamelib/ containing a couple of files derived from a template. python ./yourgamelib/init.py MyGame Build the project The user project in ./MyGame/ already contains some scripts starting with build_[..] , so we go straight ahead and try to build our project for the desktop platform by running a suitable build script. cd MyGame ./build_desktop_debug.bash If everything went fine, we now have an executable that renders something like this: a cube in a grid. Next Steps Check out the examples, the API and other target platforms.
docs.title: Getting Started

docs.title: Fundamentals

docs.text: Manual NOTE: This site is UNDER CONSTRUCTION! Init Script To integrate additional third-party libraries , use the --extProj option, like so: python <path_to_yourgamelib>/init.py MyGame --extProj box2d lua Build System yourgamelib is pulled into MyGame via CMake add_subdirectory() . This path needs to be adjusted in CMakeLists.txt if the projects are moved around. Alternatively, MyGame can be configured to clone yourgamelib by itself to make it independent of the original yourgamelib location. See template/CMakeLists.txt on how to do this. Assets (Save files, Project files) All files placed in assets/ will be packed and made available to be loaded by the application at runtime. User Code YourGame API and Namespaces Toolbox Third-party libraries Android Requirements To build for target android , you need: The Android SDK check yourgame template build.gradle ... ...and install the requested NDK version ( ndkVersion ) via sdkmanager , or change suitable ...do the same for other Android SDK components, if they are not installed automatically Gradle (tested version 6.8.3), or... ...use Android Studio. It generates a Gradle Wrapper for the project, not requiring a separate Gradle installation WebAssembly Requirements To build for target web , you need: Emscripten Make sure the environment variable EMSDK is set and points to the emsdk root directory.
docs.title: Manual

docs.text: yourgame::util::AssetManager utility to store and request pointers, and to delete dynamically allocated objects, by name More... #include <assetmanager.h> Public Functions Name ~AssetManager () template <class T > void insert (std::string name, T * obj) insert pointer. if it exists (same type T and same name), previous object is deleted and the pointer is replaced. rejects nullptrs. template <class T > void insert (std::string name, T obj) dummy for compile-time check (static_assert) of non-pointer type template <class T > T * get (std::string name) request pointer by name template <class T > size_t numOf () returns number of stored pointers of type T* template <class T > void destroy (std::string name) destroy (delete) object, remove pointer template <class T > void destroy () destroy (delete) all objects of type T, remove all pointers of type T* void clear () clear content. delete all objects, remove all pointers Detailed Description class yourgame :: util :: AssetManager ; utility to store and request pointers, and to delete dynamically allocated objects, by name Attention : type T is always the base type, not the pointer type (T*) never delete objects manually with delete if they have been stored with insert() use like so: create an object with new use insert() to store the pointer by name if it exists, previous object is deleted and the pointer is replaced use get() to request the pointer by name use destroy() to delete the object and remove the pointer by name Public Functions Documentation function ~AssetManager inline ~ AssetManager () function insert template < class T > inline void insert ( std :: string name , T * obj ) insert pointer. if it exists (same type T and same name), previous object is deleted and the pointer is replaced. rejects nullptrs. Parameters : name name obj pointer Template Parameters : T object type Attention : obj must be a pointer type only insert pointer to object, that has been created with new function insert template < class T > inline void insert ( std :: string name , T obj ) dummy for compile-time check (static_assert) of non-pointer type Parameters : name name obj pointer Template Parameters : T object type function get template < class T > inline T * get ( std :: string name ) request pointer by name Parameters : name name Template Parameters : T object type Return : pointer. nullptr, if no pointer of type T* and name exists function numOf template < class T > inline size_t numOf () returns number of stored pointers of type T* Template Parameters : T object type Return : number of stored pointers of type T* function destroy template < class T > inline void destroy ( std :: string name ) destroy (delete) object, remove pointer Parameters : name name Template Parameters : T object type function destroy template < class T > inline void destroy () destroy (delete) all objects of type T, remove all pointers of type T* Template Parameters : T object type function clear inline void clear () clear content. delete all objects, remove all pointers Updated on 2022-04-08 at 20:35:29 +0000

docs.text: Manual.md Source code # Manual > **NOTE:** This site is UNDER CONSTRUCTION! ## Init Script To integrate additional [ third-party libraries ]( thirdparty/README.md ), use the `--extProj` option, like so: ```bash python <path_to_yourgamelib>/init.py MyGame --extProj box2d lua Build System yourgamelib is pulled into MyGame via CMake add_subdirectory() . This path needs to be adjusted in CMakeLists.txt if the projects are moved around. Alternatively, MyGame can be configured to clone yourgamelib by itself to make it independent of the original yourgamelib location. See template/CMakeLists.txt on how to do this. Assets (Save files, Project files) All files placed in assets/ will be packed and made available to be loaded by the application at runtime. User Code YourGame API and Namespaces Toolbox Third-party libraries Android Requirements To build for target android , you need: The Android SDK check yourgame template build.gradle ... ...and install the requested NDK version ( ndkVersion ) via sdkmanager , or change suitable ...do the same for other Android SDK components, if they are not installed automatically Gradle (tested version 6.8.3), or... ...use Android Studio. It generates a Gradle Wrapper for the project, not requiring a separate Gradle installation WebAssembly Requirements To build for target web , you need: Emscripten Make sure the environment variable EMSDK is set and points to the emsdk root directory. ``` Updated on 2022-04-08 at 20:35:29 +0000

} } } template < class T > void destroy () { auto itMap = m_ptrMaps . find ( typeid ( T ). hash_code ()); if ( itMap != m_ptrMaps . end ()) { for ( const auto & ptr : itMap -> second ) { m_delFuncs [ itMap -> first ]( ptr . second ); } } m_ptrMaps . clear (); } private : std :: map < size_t , std :: map < std :: string , std :: uintptr_t >> m_ptrMaps ; std :: map < size_t , std :: function < void ( std :: uintptr_t ) >> m_delFuncs ; docs.text: index.md Source code # Getting Started This guide explains how to get YourGameLib, create a user project and run it. ## TL;DR If you are in a hurry, grab the pre-initialized template [ YourGameProject.zip ]( YourGameProject.zip ) and jump to [ Build the project ]( #build-the-project ). You need `Git` , `CMake` and a `C/C++ compiler` , as mentioned below. - **Pro:** Fast, easy, `Python` **not** required - **Con:** Manually rename "YourGameProject" across multiple files The recommended way for initializing a new project is following this guide, though. ## Requirements The list of requirements for getting started: - `Git 1.7.0+` - `Python 3.5+` with - `Jinja2` - `gitpython` - `CMake 3.6+` - A common `C/C++ compiler` capable of C++11 ## Installation With YourGameLib, user projects get access to the YourGame API and a selected number of third-party libraries, to work with directly. YourGameLib is always built from source in user project context. Let's get the code by cloning the repository: ```bash git clone --depth 1 https://github.com/duddel/yourgamelib.git Installation done. Initialize a User Project Initialize a new user project by running the init.py script from the just cloned yourgamelib directory. This creates the directory ./MyGame/ next to ./yourgamelib/ containing a couple of files derived from a template. python ./yourgamelib/init.py MyGame Build the project The user project in ./MyGame/ already contains some scripts starting with build_[..] , so we go straight ahead and try to build our project for the desktop platform by running a suitable build script. cd MyGame ./build_desktop_debug.bash If everything went fine, we now have an executable that renders something like this: a cube in a grid. Next Steps Check out the examples, the API and other target platforms. ``` Updated on 2022-04-08 at 20:35:29 +0000

docs.text: The user project in ./MyGame/ already contains some scripts starting with build_[..] , so we go straight ahead and try to build our project for the desktop platform by running a suitable build script. cd MyGame ./build_desktop_debug.bash If everything went fine, we now have an executable that renders something like this: a cube in a grid.

docs.text: mygame User functions that are linked to and called by the yourgame library framework. More... Functions Name void init (int argc, char * argv[]) user project initialization void tick () user project update/draw (once pre frame) int shutdown () user project clean-up Detailed Description User functions that are linked to and called by the yourgame library framework. The yourgame library expects the functions in the mygame namespace to be implemented. They are called by the yourgame library framework at specific moments. The underlying application logic (main function) is provided by the framework. Implementing these functions is mandatory and makes the user project executable together with the yourgame library. Functions Documentation function init void init ( int argc , char * argv [] ) user project initialization Parameters : argc number of arguments argv arguments, forwarded from main() (C style application args) called by the yourgame framework after it has been initialized function tick void tick () user project update/draw (once pre frame) called by the yourgame framework once per frame function shutdown int shutdown () user project clean-up called by the yourgame framework before it is shut down Updated on 2022-04-08 at 20:35:29 +0000

docs.text: yourgame::file file and path related functions Functions Name std::string getSaveFilePath (const std::string & filename ="") returns the full (absolut) path to a file called filename in the save file location std::string getProjectFilePath (const std::string & filename ="") returns the full (absolut) path to a file called filename in the project file location int readAssetFile (const std::string & filename, std::vector< uint8_t > & dst) reads an entire file (from asset file location) and returns it as a vector of bytes int readSaveFile (const std::string & filename, std::vector< uint8_t > & dst) reads an entire file (from save file location) and returns it as a vector of bytes int readProjectFile (const std::string & filename, std::vector< uint8_t > & dst) reads an entire file (from project file location) and returns it as a vector of bytes void setProjectPath (const std::string & path) sets path as current project directory. initial project directory is "" int readFile (const std::string & filename, std::vector< uint8_t > & dst) reads an entire file and returns it as a vector of bytes std::string getFileLocation (const std::string & filepath) returns the location (path or prefix, such as a//) of a file, filepath points to std::string getFileName (const std::string & filepath) returns the actual file name of a file, filepath points to std::string getFileExtension (const std::string & filepath) returns the file extension int writeAssetFile (const std::string & filename, const void * data, size_t numBytes) writes numBytes bytes from data to a file called filename in the asset file location. overwrites the file if it exists int writeSaveFile (const std::string & filename, const void * data, size_t numBytes) writes numBytes bytes from data to a file called filename in the save file location. overwrites the file if it exists int writeProjectFile (const std::string & filename, const void * data, size_t numBytes) writes numBytes bytes from data to a file called filename in the project file location. overwrites the file if it exists int writeFile (const std::string & filename, const void * data, size_t numBytes) writes numBytes bytes from data to a file called filename, destination path determined by prefix ("a//", etc.), see readFile() . overwrites the file if it exists. std::vector< std::string > ls (const std::string & pattern) returns list of directory content. accepts prefixes like readFile() does. accepts wildcard "*" for files (after last / in pattern) Functions Documentation function getSaveFilePath std :: string getSaveFilePath ( const std :: string & filename = "" ) returns the full (absolut) path to a file called filename in the save file location function getProjectFilePath std :: string getProjectFilePath ( const std :: string & filename = "" ) returns the full (absolut) path to a file called filename in the project file location function readAssetFile int readAssetFile ( const std :: string & filename , std :: vector < uint8_t > & dst ) reads an entire file (from asset file location) and returns it as a vector of bytes function readSaveFile int readSaveFile ( const std :: string & filename , std :: vector < uint8_t > & dst ) reads an entire file (from save file location) and returns it as a vector of bytes function readProjectFile int readProjectFile ( const std :: string & filename , std :: vector < uint8_t > & dst ) reads an entire file (from project file location) and returns it as a vector of bytes function setProjectPath void setProjectPath ( const std :: string & path ) sets path as current project directory. initial project directory is "" function readFile int readFile ( const std :: string & filename , std :: vector < uint8_t > & dst ) reads an entire file and returns it as a vector of bytes prepend a// to load a file from asset file location prepend s// to load a file from save file location prepend p// to load a file from project file location prepend none of the above to load a file with unchanged filename as path example: loadFile("a//file1.bin" ...) // loads file1.bin from assets example: loadFile("s//file2.bin" ...) // loads file2.bin from save file location example: loadFile("p//file3.bin" ...) // loads file3.bin from project file location example: loadFile("file4.bin" ...) // loads file4.bin from working directory function getFileLocation std :: string getFileLocation ( const std :: string & filepath ) returns the location (path or prefix, such as a//) of a file, filepath points to example: "file1.bin" returns "" example: "a//file2.bin" returns "a//" example: "/home/user/file3.bin" returns "/home/user/" function getFileName std :: string getFileName ( const std :: string & filepath ) returns the actual file name of a file, filepath points to example: "file1.bin" returns "file1.bin" example: "a//file2.bin" returns "file2.bin" example: "/home/user/file3.bin" returns "file3.bin" function getFileExtension std :: string getFileExtension ( const std :: string & filepath ) returns the file extension example: "file1.bin" returns "bin" example: "a//texture.png" returns "png" example: ".gitignore" returns "gitignore" example: "Makefile" returns "" function writeAssetFile int writeAssetFile ( const std :: string & filename , const void * data , size_t numBytes ) writes numBytes bytes from data to a file called filename in the asset file location. overwrites the file if it exists function writeSaveFile int writeSaveFile ( const std :: string & filename , const void * data , size_t numBytes ) writes numBytes bytes from data to a file called filename in the save file location. overwrites the file if it exists function writeProjectFile int writeProjectFile ( const std :: string & filename , const void * data , size_t numBytes ) writes numBytes bytes from data to a file called filename in the project file location. overwrites the file if it exists function writeFile int writeFile ( const std :: string & filename , const void * data , size_t numBytes ) writes numBytes bytes from data to a file called filename, destination path determined by prefix ("a//", etc.), see readFile() . overwrites the file if it exists. Attention : filename requires a prefix, such as "a//". otherwise, writing is omitted. function ls std :: vector < std :: string > ls ( const std :: string & pattern ) returns list of directory content. accepts prefixes like readFile() does. accepts wildcard "*" for files (after last / in pattern) Updated on 2022-04-08 at 20:35:29 +0000

docs.text: std :: string getSaveFilePath ( const std :: string & filename = "" ) returns the full (absolut) path to a file called filename in the save file location
docs.title: function getSaveFilePath

docs.text: std :: string getProjectFilePath ( const std :: string & filename = "" ) returns the full (absolut) path to a file called filename in the project file location
docs.title: function getProjectFilePath

docs.text: int readAssetFile ( const std :: string & filename , std :: vector < uint8_t > & dst ) reads an entire file (from asset file location) and returns it as a vector of bytes
docs.title: function readAssetFile

docs.text: int readSaveFile ( const std :: string & filename , std :: vector < uint8_t > & dst ) reads an entire file (from save file location) and returns it as a vector of bytes
docs.title: function readSaveFile

docs.text: int readProjectFile ( const std :: string & filename , std :: vector < uint8_t > & dst ) reads an entire file (from project file location) and returns it as a vector of bytes
docs.title: function readProjectFile

docs.text: void setProjectPath ( const std :: string & path ) sets path as current project directory. initial project directory is ""
docs.title: function setProjectPath

docs.text: int readFile ( const std :: string & filename , std :: vector < uint8_t > & dst ) reads an entire file and returns it as a vector of bytes prepend a// to load a file from asset file location prepend s// to load a file from save file location prepend p// to load a file from project file location prepend none of the above to load a file with unchanged filename as path example: loadFile("a//file1.bin" ...) // loads file1.bin from assets example: loadFile("s//file2.bin" ...) // loads file2.bin from save file location example: loadFile("p//file3.bin" ...) // loads file3.bin from project file location example: loadFile("file4.bin" ...) // loads file4.bin from working directory
docs.title: function readFile

docs.text: std :: string getFileLocation ( const std :: string & filepath ) returns the location (path or prefix, such as a//) of a file, filepath points to example: "file1.bin" returns "" example: "a//file2.bin" returns "a//" example: "/home/user/file3.bin" returns "/home/user/"
docs.title: function getFileLocation

docs.text: std :: string getFileName ( const std :: string & filepath ) returns the actual file name of a file, filepath points to example: "file1.bin" returns "file1.bin" example: "a//file2.bin" returns "file2.bin" example: "/home/user/file3.bin" returns "file3.bin"
docs.title: function getFileName

docs.text: std :: string getFileExtension ( const std :: string & filepath ) returns the file extension example: "file1.bin" returns "bin" example: "a//texture.png" returns "png" example: ".gitignore" returns "gitignore" example: "Makefile" returns ""
docs.title: function getFileExtension

docs.text: int writeAssetFile ( const std :: string & filename , const void * data , size_t numBytes ) writes numBytes bytes from data to a file called filename in the asset file location. overwrites the file if it exists
docs.title: function writeAssetFile

docs.text: int writeSaveFile ( const std :: string & filename , const void * data , size_t numBytes ) writes numBytes bytes from data to a file called filename in the save file location. overwrites the file if it exists
docs.title: function writeSaveFile

docs.text: int writeProjectFile ( const std :: string & filename , const void * data , size_t numBytes ) writes numBytes bytes from data to a file called filename in the project file location. overwrites the file if it exists
docs.title: function writeProjectFile

docs.text: int writeFile ( const std :: string & filename , const void * data , size_t numBytes ) writes numBytes bytes from data to a file called filename, destination path determined by prefix ("a//", etc.), see readFile() . overwrites the file if it exists. Attention : filename requires a prefix, such as "a//". otherwise, writing is omitted.
docs.title: function writeFile

docs.text: std :: vector < std :: string > ls ( const std :: string & pattern ) returns list of directory content. accepts prefixes like readFile() does. accepts wildcard "*" for files (after last / in pattern) Updated on 2022-04-08 at 20:35:29 +0000
docs.title: function ls

docs.text: Template Example #include "yourgame/yourgame.h" #include "mygame_version.h" namespace yg = yourgame ; // convenience namespace mygame { yg :: util :: AssetManager g_assets ; yg :: math :: Camera g_camera ; yg :: math :: Trafo g_modelTrafo ; yg :: gl :: Lightsource g_light ; void init ( int argc , char * argv []) { yg :: log :: info ( "project: %v (%v)" , mygame :: version :: PROJECT_NAME , mygame :: version :: git_commit ); yg :: log :: info ( "based on: %v (%v)" , yg :: version :: PROJECT_NAME , yg :: version :: git_commit ); g_camera . trafo () -> lookAt ( glm :: vec3 ( 7.35889f , 4.95831f , 6.92579f ), glm :: vec3 ( 0.0f , 0.0f , 0.0f ), glm :: vec3 ( 0.0f , 1.0f , 0.0f )); g_camera . setPerspective ( 40.0f , yg :: input :: get ( yg :: input :: WINDOW_ASPECT_RATIO ), 1.0f , 100.0f ); g_light . setPosition ({ 4.07625f , 5.90386f , -1.00545f }); g_light . setDiffuse ({ 1.0f , 1.0f , 1.0f }); g_assets . insert ( "geoCube" , yg :: gl :: loadGeometry ( "a//cube.obj" )); g_assets . insert ( "geoGrid" , yg :: gl :: loadGeometry ( "a//grid.obj" )); g_assets . insert ( "shaderDiffuseColor" , yg :: gl :: loadShader ({{ GL_VERTEX_SHADER , "a//default.vert" }, { GL_FRAGMENT_SHADER , "a//diffusecolor.frag" }})); g_assets . insert ( "shaderSimpleColor" , yg :: gl :: loadShader ({{ GL_VERTEX_SHADER , "a//default.vert" }, { GL_FRAGMENT_SHADER , "a//simplecolor.frag" }})); glClearColor ( 0.275f , 0.275f , 0.275f , 1.0f ); glEnable ( GL_DEPTH_TEST ); } void tick () { g_camera . setAspect ( yg :: input :: get ( yg :: input :: WINDOW_ASPECT_RATIO )); glViewport ( 0 , 0 , yg :: input :: geti ( yg :: input :: WINDOW_WIDTH ), yg :: input :: geti ( yg :: input :: WINDOW_HEIGHT )); glClear ( GL_COLOR_BUFFER_BIT | GL_DEPTH_BUFFER_BIT ); if ( yg :: input :: get ( yg :: input :: KEY_ESCAPE )) { yg :: control :: exit (); } // first-person camera g_camera . trafo () -> rotateGlobal ( static_cast < float > ( yg :: time :: getDelta ()) * 0.75f * yg :: input :: get ( yg :: input :: KEY_LEFT ), yg :: math :: Axis :: Y ); g_camera . trafo () -> rotateGlobal ( static_cast < float > ( yg :: time :: getDelta ()) * -0.75f * yg :: input :: get ( yg :: input :: KEY_RIGHT ), yg :: math :: Axis :: Y ); g_camera . trafo () -> rotateLocal ( static_cast < float > ( yg :: time :: getDelta ()) * 0.75f * yg :: input :: get ( yg :: input :: KEY_UP ), yg :: math :: Axis :: X ); g_camera . trafo () -> rotateLocal ( static_cast < float > ( yg :: time :: getDelta ()) * -0.75f * yg :: input :: get ( yg :: input :: KEY_DOWN ), yg :: math :: Axis :: X ); g_camera . trafo () -> translateLocal ( static_cast < float > ( yg :: time :: getDelta ()) * -5.0f * yg :: input :: get ( yg :: input :: KEY_W ), yg :: math :: Axis :: Z ); g_camera . trafo () -> translateLocal ( static_cast < float > ( yg :: time :: getDelta ()) * 5.0f * yg :: input :: get ( yg :: input :: KEY_S ), yg :: math :: Axis :: Z ); g_camera . trafo () -> translateLocal ( static_cast < float > ( yg :: time :: getDelta ()) * 5.0f * yg :: input :: get ( yg :: input :: KEY_D ), yg :: math :: Axis :: X ); g_camera . trafo () -> translateLocal ( static_cast < float > ( yg :: time :: getDelta ()) * -5.0f * yg :: input :: get ( yg :: input :: KEY_A ), yg :: math :: Axis :: X ); // fade light static float lightT = 0.0f ; float light = std :: cos ( lightT ) * 0.5f + 0.5f ; g_light . setDiffuse ({ light , light , light }); lightT += ( static_cast < float > ( yg :: time :: getDelta ()) * 0.65f ); // draw cube { auto shdrDiffCol = g_assets . get < yg :: gl :: Shader > ( "shaderDiffuseColor" ); shdrDiffCol -> useProgram ( & g_light , & g_camera ); yg :: gl :: DrawConfig cfg ; cfg . camera = & g_camera ; cfg . modelMat = g_modelTrafo . mat (); cfg . shader = shdrDiffCol ; yg :: gl :: drawGeo ( g_assets . get < yg :: gl :: Geometry > ( "geoCube" ), cfg ); } // draw grid { auto shdrSimpCol = g_assets . get < yg :: gl :: Shader > ( "shaderSimpleColor" ); shdrSimpCol -> useProgram ( nullptr , & g_camera ); yg :: gl :: DrawConfig cfg ; cfg . camera = & g_camera ; cfg . shader = shdrSimpCol ; yg :: gl :: drawGeo ( g_assets . get < yg :: gl :: Geometry > ( "geoGrid" ), cfg ); } } int shutdown () { g_assets . clear (); return 0 ; } } // namespace mygame Filename: mygame.cpp Updated on 2022-04-08 at 20:35:29 +0000

docs.text: Manual NOTE: This site is UNDER CONSTRUCTION! Init Script To integrate additional third-party libraries, use the --extProj option, like so: python <path_to_yourgamelib>/init.py MyGame --extProj box2d lua Build System yourgamelib is pulled into MyGame via CMake add_subdirectory() . This path needs to be adjusted in CMakeLists.txt if the projects are moved around. Alternatively, MyGame can be configured to clone yourgamelib by itself to make it independent of the original yourgamelib location. See template/CMakeLists.txt on how to do this. Assets (Save files, Project files) All files placed in assets/ will be packed and made available to be loaded by the application at runtime. User Code YourGame API and Namespaces Toolbox Third-party libraries Android Requirements To build for target android , you need: The Android SDK check yourgame template build.gradle ... ...and install the requested NDK version ( ndkVersion ) via sdkmanager , or change suitable ...do the same for other Android SDK components, if they are not installed automatically Gradle (tested version 6.8.3), or... ...use Android Studio. It generates a Gradle Wrapper for the project, not requiring a separate Gradle installation WebAssembly Requirements To build for target web , you need: Emscripten Make sure the environment variable EMSDK is set and points to the emsdk root directory. Updated on 2022-04-08 at 20:35:29 +0000

docs.text: Getting Started This guide explains how to get YourGameLib, create a user project and run it. TL;DR If you are in a hurry, grab the pre-initialized template YourGameProject.zip and jump to Build the project . You need Git , CMake and a C/C++ compiler , as mentioned below. Pro: Fast, easy, Python not required Con: Manually rename "YourGameProject" across multiple files The recommended way for initializing a new project is following this guide, though. Requirements The list of requirements for getting started: Git 1.7.0+ Python 3.5+ with Jinja2 gitpython CMake 3.6+ A common C/C++ compiler capable of C++11 Installation With YourGameLib, user projects get access to the YourGame API and a selected number of third-party libraries, to work with directly. YourGameLib is always built from source in user project context. Let's get the code by cloning the repository: git clone --depth 1 https://github.com/duddel/yourgamelib.git Installation done. Initialize a User Project Initialize a new user project by running the init.py script from the just cloned yourgamelib directory. This creates the directory ./MyGame/ next to ./yourgamelib/ containing a couple of files derived from a template. python ./yourgamelib/init.py MyGame Build the project The user project in ./MyGame/ already contains some scripts starting with build_[..] , so we go straight ahead and try to build our project for the desktop platform by running a suitable build script. cd MyGame ./build_desktop_debug.bash If everything went fine, we now have an executable that renders something like this: a cube in a grid. Next Steps Check out the examples, the API and other target platforms. Updated on 2022-04-08 at 20:35:29 +0000
